awd_abstract_narration:
General Relativity is Einstein's theory of gravity that interprets gravity as a consequence of the curvature of spacetime. The theory predicts the existence of black holes via solutions to the Einstein equation. The first image of a black hole, recently obtained by astronomers using Event Horizon Telescope (EHT), has given remarkable evidence to the accuracy of this theory. The aim of this proposal is to investigate the geometry of space regions in general relativity, which in particular include regions surrounding a black hole. Results from this project will shed new light on the gravitational energy confined in a finite region, as well as the contribution of black holes to such quasi-local energy.

In geometric terms, the PI aims at studying manifolds with non-negative scalar curvature, with boundary. The goal is to obtain new understanding of the interaction among scalar curvature, boundary mean curvature, interior minimal surfaces, volume of compact manifolds, and mass of asymptotically flat manifolds. The PI willl also establish a Poincare-type inequality on the boundary of compact manifolds with non-negative scalar curvature. The PI will employ geometric and analytic methods from calculus of variation and partial differential equations to achieve these goals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has produced new outcomes on the following topics: estimates of quasi-local mass in general relativity; geometric detection of relativistic mass via polyhedra; and connections among harmonic functions, capacity, mass and scalar curvature.

The problem of determining the relativistic mass contained in a finite region is a long-standing open problem in general relativity, known as the quasi-local mass problem. In this project, new estimates of an important quasi-local mass, the Bartnik quasi-local mass, were obtained. The estimates are sharp in the case of zero mean curvature or boundary metric approaching a round metric. Motivated by the quasi-local mass problem, new results concerning nonnegative scalar curvature fill-ins of a given surface were also found.

The mass of asymptotically flat spaces is a classic concept in general relativity. In this project, new methods were discovered to detect the mass via geometric data associated to large Riemannian polyhedra approaching the infinity of the space. Such results reveal new links between differential geometry and mathematical relativity.

Harmonic functions are basic objects in mathematical analysis. Scalar curvature is a fundamental invariant of curvature in differential geometry. Capacity and mass are important quantities associated to surfaces and asymptotically flat spaces in classic physics and general relativity. In this project, new results were found which unveiled previously unknown connections among these subjects. These outcomes have already motivated subsequent research on related topics by other researchers.
